ygData.msgSnippet: Kirk, what is your idea for applying CPPNs to pattern recognition?  I am not sure I followed exactly how the CPPN would be connected to the neural network? As

Kirk, what is your idea for applying CPPNs to pattern recognition?  I
am no=
t sure I followed exactly how the CPPN would be connected to the
neural net=
work?

As Peter mentioned, we have used the idea of CPPNs to represent
conn=
ectivity patterns rather than the spatial patterns you saw in the
CPPN pape=
r.  These connectivity patterns can then be interpreted of
neural network c=
onnectivity patterns, which means you can evolve
neural networks with regul=
arities in their connectivities.  There are
currently four papers on this a=
pproach to evolving ANNs with CPPNs,
which is called HyperNEAT.  Those pape=
rs are available from my homepage

http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/

or fro=
m EPlex publications:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications.html

The parti=
cular papers are:

-A Novel Generative Encoding for Exploiting Neural Netwo=
rk Sensor and 
Output Geometry

-Generating Large-Scale Neural Networks Thr=
ough Discovering Geometric
Regularities 

-A Case Study on the Critical Rol=
e of Geometric Regularity in Machine
Learning

-Generative Encoding for Mul=
tiagent Learning 

A longer journal paper on HyperNEAT is also forthcoming =
in Artificial
Life journal.

By the way, you can also interactively evolve =
your own CPPNs images
online at http://picbreeder.org

Because spatial patt=
erns and connectivity patterns can represent just
about anything, there are=
 other potential applications of CPPNs beyond
representing ANNs, but curren=
tly there is no publication of such an
application that I know of.  But it =
would be interesting to see more
work in that direction.

ken 


--- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hyp=
erNEAT uses CPPNs to build the neural network phenotypes (and 
> evolves CP=
PNs). I see this as an extension. There are about 3 or more 
> papers on Hy=
perNEAT. It should be interesting to you, though it is just 
> one of all p=
ossible applications. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "newtwi=
st2000" <rkdelisle@> wrote:
> >
> > I've just read through the paper Compos=
itional Pattern Producing
> > Networks: A Novel Abstraction of Development =
- very interesting stuff.
> >  
> > Are there additional papers that extend=
 on this?  Currently what I'm
> > seeing is based on visual representations=
, but are there papers where
> > this has been extended to pattern recognit=
ion or other fields?  My
> > thought is that if a CPPN can capture importan=
t spatial details that
> > can then be evaluated by a standard NN, can the =
two improve on pattern
> > recognition tasks that have a relative spatial c=
omponent -
> > topological, geometric, higher dimensions...
> > 
> > -Kirk
